Name:  ___              Unit No:   ___

Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F

Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
fever, wheezing, abdominal pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ TEE
 
History of Present Illness:
___ coming from nursing home with h/o schizoaffective disorder, 
HTN, afib on Eliquis, dementia, HLD, kidney failure on home 
oxygen presents from facility with c/o fever (Tmax 102), 
wheezing, and distended abdomen. 

ED Course notable for:  

Initial CXR concerning for infection with patchy retrocardiac 
opacity. CBC with leukocytosis to 20.5. Lactate trending up from 
2.4 to 4.2. Patient was given 500mL NS and started on vancomycin 
and zosyn. A CT was performed, also concerning for PNA and 
redemonstrating previously known stercoral colitis with stool 
ball and porcelain gallbladder.

In the ED BP was 94/66 not on pressors. Access is 1 peripheral 
20 guage iv. 

On arrival to the MICU, the patient is somnolent but arousable 
to pain or raised voice. When asked if she has pain, she shakes 
her head no. Her O2 sat is ~96% on 6L NC. 
 
Past Medical History:
(per chart, unable to confirm with patient):
AFib on Eliquis
Mitral valve insufficiency/mitral valve prolapse s/p repair
Stroke with resultant contracture R hand
Schizoaffective disorder with hx of catatonia requiring ECT
Panic disorder
Seizure disorder
HTN
GERD
B12 deficiency
Chronic hypernatremia
NSTEMI ___
bipolar disease
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
(per chart, unable to confirm with pt):
Father with bipolar disorder.  Multiple mentally ill relatives 
(all 
siblings have mental illness diagnosis except for one). Per her 
guardian, her nephew also has a major mental illness.

IMAGING:
CHEST (PORTABLE AP)Study Date of ___ 10:05 ___
Patchy retrocardiac opacity, potentially atelectasis, with 
infection not
excluded in the correct clinical setting.  No evidence for 
congestive heart
failure.

CT CHEST W/O CONTRAST; 
CT ABD & PELVIS W/O CONTRAST     Study Date of ___ 10:18 
___
1. Slightly limited assessment of the lung parenchyma due to 
motion.  Within
these limitations, bilateral, relatively diffuse 
peribronchovascular, nodular
ground-glass opacities, right greater than left, are suggestive 
of underlying
infectious or inflammatory process.
2. Large rectosigmoid stool ball is similar in size compared to 
prior with
rectal and sigmoid wall thickening consistent with stercoral 
proctitis. 
Recommend disimpaction.
3. Cholelithiasis without acute cholecystitis. Calcification of 
the periphery
of the gallbladder compatible with porcelain gallbladder, as 
seen previously.

___ Cardiovascular Transthoracic Echo Report 
IMPRESSION: No 2D echocardiographic evidence for endocarditis. 
Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity 
size and regional/global biventricular systolic function. 
Thickened
mitral valve with mildly elevated transvalvular gradient. Mild 
mitral and tricuspid regurgitation. mild pulmonary hypertension.
***Transesophageal Echo done on ___, per fellow no 
evidence of vegetations, full report not finalized in our 
medical record at time of discharge. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year old female nursing home resident with guardian 
with past medical history of atrial fibrillation, prior stroke 
with residual L hemiparesis, CKD stage 3, mitral valve prolapse 
status post repair, schizoaffective disorder, seizure disorder, 
admitted ___ with sepsis secondary to stercoral colitis 
and strep bovis bacteremia, treated with antibiotics with 
improvement, TEE without signs of endocarditis, able to be 
discharged to nursing home

# Sepsis, Strep Bovis secondary to acute blood stream infection 
# Stercoral colitis 
Patient presented with fever, leukocytosis, without clear source 
of infection.  Patient initially admitted to ICU on empiric 
broad spectrum antibiotics, where admission blood cultures 
returned positive for strep bovis.  CT imaging showed large 
stool ball in the sigmoid colon and rectum. She was felt to 
likely have translocation of gut bacteria in setting of this 
stercoral colitis.  Antibiotics were narrowed based on 
sensitivities and patient was treated with aggressive bowel 
regimen with resolution of constipation symptoms and abdominal 
distension.  TTE and TEE did not demonstrate signs of 
endocarditis. A midline was placed and her last day of 
ceftriaxone will be ___ for a full 14 day course of 
ceftriaxone. Discharged with a more aggressive bowel regimen to 
avoid future obstipation. 

# Acute Metabolic Encephalopathy 
Patient was lethargic on presentation in setting of sepsis.  
Initial medical workup was unremarkable, except for above sepsis 
and infection.  Her mental status resolved to her baseline with 
the above and she remained stable. 

#HYPERNATRMEMIA: 
In setting of her acute infection,  patients sodium peaked at 
154, thought to be secondary to increased insensible losses.  
Increased patient free water flushes to compensate.  Sodium was 
subsequently stable.  Final free water flush regimen was 300 cc 
q4h.  Would recheck sodium to ensure stability.  

# ___ 
# CKD 3 
Patient presented with elevated Cr to 2.2 on presentation. Her 
baseline is 1.2.  Thought to be dehydration and sepsis, both of 
which were treated as above. Also found to have urinary 
retention, treated as below.  Cr resolved to baseline prior to 
discharge. 

# Urinary retention 
Found to be retaining 1.3L urine on presentation.  Felt to be 
from her encephalopathy and constipation.  Initially had foley 
placed.  Passed subsequent trial of void and retention did not 
recur.  

# Chronic Afib c/b CVA
Continued apixaban, metoprolol

# Schizoaffective disorder
Given initial sedation, home Seroquel and clonazepam were held.  
Given stability of mental status at baseline, did not restart 
Seroquel or clonazepam--would consider restarting at follow-up. 

#Porcelain Gallbladder
Incidentally seen on imaging, stable from prior.  Would consider 
outpatient surgical referral

#Seizure disorder 
Continued valproic acid

#GERD 
- continued famotidine

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: 
- Discharged to nursing home
- Consider repeat Na check
- Consider re-starting clonazepam and quetiapine as needed, but 
the patient was not requiring these medications at discharge
- Follow up porcelain gallbladder, discussing with guardian 
___ how aggressively she would want to follow this 
- Spoke to ___ prior to discharge and she would like for the 
patient to remain NPO with tube feeds to reduce risk of 
aspiration. Also spoke with her re: colonoscopy and she does not 
want to pursue this given that treatment of cancer is not within 
the patient's goals of care
- Last day of ceftriaxone will be ___. Please pull midline 
after that. 
- Discharged on modified free water flush regimen: 300 cc q4h

> 30 minutes spent on discharge

qafib.question: Does the note describe the patient as having permanent, paroxysmal, or persistent afib?

qprior_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having a stroke or transient ischemic attack?

qarterial_hypertension.question: Does the note describe the patient as having arterial hypertension on treatment (high bp e.g. >140, or HTN)?

qt2d.question: Does the note describe the patient as having Diabetes mellitus (DM1, DM2, T2D, T1DM, T2DM)?

qheart_failure.question: Does the note describe the patient as having heart failure?

qsurgical_valvular_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having valvular disease requiring surgery (stenosis)?

qafib_ablation.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a planned or past ablation procedure for afib?

qbleeding.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a serious bleeding in the past 6 months?

qpeptic_ulcer_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having peptic ulcer disease?

qrecent_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a stroke during this admission or within the last month? (Answer yes for any recent stroke if the date is unclear)

qhemorrhagic.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having any hemorrhagic tendencies or blood dyscrasias?

qbipolar.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with bipolar disorder?

qschizophrenia.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with schizophrenia or any schizoaffective disorders?

qmdd.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with depression or major depressive disorder (MDD)?

qmed_decisions.question: Does the note describe the patient as being unable to make medical decisions? (Answer no unless there is evidence the patient cannot make their own medical decisions).

qchads2.question: What is the highest CHADS2 score mentioned? Answer "NA" if no CHADS2 score is in the note.

qblood_glucose.question: What is the highest blood glucose lab mentioned? Answer "NA" if no blood glucose score is in the note.

qlvef.question: What is the lowest left ventricular ejection (LVEF, ef, ejection fraction) fraction mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no LVEF is in the note, Answer 55 if the lowest value is 55% or greater.

qPLT.question: What is the lowest platelet count (PLT) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no platelet count is available in the note.

qHGB.question: What is the lowest hemoglobin (HGB) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no HGB value is available in the note.

qCREAT.question: What is the higest serum creatinine (Creat) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no creatinine value is available in the note.

qAST.question: What is the higest aspartate aminotransferase level (AST) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no AST value is available in the note.

qBILI.question: What is the higest total bilirubin (TotBili, Bili) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no bilirubin value is available in the note.
